G.L. c. 185C, \u00a73.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction pursuant to G.L. c. 185C, §3 and G.L. c. 212, §4, as this action arises out of a landlord-tenant relationship within the jurisdictional boundaries of the Boston Housing Court Department.

G.L. c. 212, \u00a74.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction pursuant to G.L. c. 185C, §3 and G.L. c. 212, §4, as this action arises out of a landlord-tenant relationship within the jurisdictional boundaries of the Boston Housing Court Department.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a714.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, §14, a landlord shall not directly or indirectly interfere with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the premises.

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850 (.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is implicit in every residential tenancy, protecting tenants against acts or omissions that substantially impair their beneficial use of the leased premises.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850 (.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states that G.L. c. 186, § 14 codified tenants’ common‑law rights under the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, confirming that such a covenant is implied in tenancies. While the case’s main focus is on the fault standard (negligence or higher) for liability, it relies on prior quiet enjoyment cases (Simon, Cruz, Darmetko, etc.) that involve substantial impairment of the tenant’s use, thereby implicitly recognizing that the covenant protects the tenant’s beneficial use of the premises. However, the opinion does not succinctly restate the proposition in those exact words, so the support is indirect rather than explicit.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850 (.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 186, § 14, originally enacted in 1927, codified a tenant’s common law rights under the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment. St. 1927, c. 339, § 1. See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 101-102 (1982). … We noted that a landlord’s failure ‘to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.’ See Cruz, supra at 789, citing Simon v. Solomon, supra at 103 (failure to control floods in tenant’s apartment); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979) (failure to repair leaky roof)….”}овый```**Note**: The "```**Note**" text at the end of the "relevant_excerpt" field should be removed as it is not part of the case excerpt. Please keep only the quoted passage from the opinion.}

Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.raw_text: Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196, 200 (1979)
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.proposition: Persistent water leaks, failure to repair material defects, and resulting mold or uninhabitable conditions have repeatedly been found to constitute violations of this covenant.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.support_reasoning: The case does involve a breach of the implied warranty of habitability, but it is based on intermittent loss of heat and hot water, not on persistent water leaks, failure to repair resulting in mold, or uninhabitable conditions caused by leaks. The opinion nowhere discusses water leaks, mold, or similar conditions; its holding concerns rent abatement timing and strict liability once the landlord has notice of serious defects. Thus, citing this case specifically for the proposition about water leaks and mold is inaccurate.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “He found and ruled that the losses of heat and hot water were material breaches of the warranty of habitability… A dwelling afflicted with a substantial Sanitary Code violation is not habitable. The essential objective of the warranty is to make sure that the tenant receives what she is paying for.”

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 718.proposition: Persistent water leaks, failure to repair material defects, and resulting mold or uninhabitable conditions have repeatedly been found to constitute violations of this covenant.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 718.support_reasoning: The case concerns constructive eviction and breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment caused by excessive noise from a lounge the landlord introduced and could control. It does not address water leaks, failure to repair material defects, mold, or uninhabitable conditions arising from such physical defects. While it supports the broader principle that substantial interference with habitability can breach quiet enjoyment, it does not specifically involve or hold that persistent water leaks or mold constitute such a violation.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 718.relevant_excerpt: “Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable. Tenants such as these should not be left only with a claim against the proprietors of the noisome lounge.”

G.L. c. 239, \u00a78A.proposition: Defendant had actual notice of the leak condition and its worsening state yet failed to take timely and adequate steps to repair it, in violation of statutory and common-law obligations under G.L. c. 239, §8A, G.L. c. 186, §§14 and 15F, and the Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7\u00a714 and 15F.proposition: Defendant had actual notice of the leak condition and its worsening state yet failed to take timely and adequate steps to repair it, in violation of statutory and common-law obligations under G.L. c. 239, §8A, G.L. c. 186, §§14 and 15F, and the Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq.

Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, 105 C.raw_text: Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq.
Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, 105 C.proposition: Defendant had actual notice of the leak condition and its worsening state yet failed to take timely and adequate steps to repair it, in violation of statutory and common-law obligations under G.L. c. 239, §8A, G.L. c. 186, §§14 and 15F, and the Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq.

Sargent v. Fuller, 46 Mass. App. Ct. 909.raw_text: Sargent v. Fuller, 46 Mass. App. Ct. 909 (1999)
Sargent v. Fuller, 46 Mass. App. Ct. 909.proposition: Such omissions constitute a substantial interference with Plaintiff’s tenancy and quiet enjoyment, similar to the violations recognized in Sargent v. Fuller, 46 Mass. App. Ct. 909 (1999) (sustained interference through landlord’s inaction); Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (1982) (constructive eviction through repeated flooding and failure to repair); Winchester v. McCue, 385 Mass. 144, 147 (1982) (chronic leaks and disrepair amounted to breach); and Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982) (water leaks and mold held actionable).
Sargent v. Fuller, 46 Mass. App. Ct. 909.support_reasoning: The opinion in Sargent v. Fuller is a criminal appeal involving rape and indecent assault charges, focusing on evidentiary rulings (rape-shield statute, expert testimony on chlamydia, impeachment, prior inconsistent statements, and prosecutor’s closing). It does not address landlord-tenant law, quiet enjoyment, interference with tenancy, constructive eviction, or conditions of leased premises. Therefore, it cannot support the proposition that omissions by a landlord constitute substantial interference with tenancy and quiet enjoyment.
Sargent v. Fuller, 46 Mass. App. Ct. 909.relevant_excerpt: On appeal from convictions by a jury on indictments charging him with rape of a child under sixteen years of age (G. L. c. 265, § 22A) and indecent assault and battery on a child under age fourteen (G. L. c. 265, § 13B), the defendant claims error in the exclusion of evidence under G. L. c. 233, § 21B, the so-called “rape-shield” statute; in the refusal to allow impeachment of the victim with a prior inconsistent statement; and in the prosecutor’s closing argument. We see no error and affirm the convictions.

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (198.proposition: Such omissions constitute a substantial interference with Plaintiff’s tenancy and quiet enjoyment, similar to the violations recognized in Sargent v. Fuller, 46 Mass. App. Ct. 909 (1999) (sustained interference through landlord’s inaction); Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (1982) (constructive eviction through repeated flooding and failure to repair); Winchester v. McCue, 385 Mass. 144, 147 (1982) (chronic leaks and disrepair amounted to breach); and Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982) (water leaks and mold held actionable).
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (198.support_reasoning: The proposition cites Simon for the idea that substantial, repeated water intrusions and a landlord’s failure to repair can amount to a serious interference with tenancy and quiet enjoyment/constructive eviction. In Simon, the SJC held the landlord liable where the tenant’s basement apartment flooded with water and sewage about thirty times, the landlord repeatedly failed to make permanent repairs, and the court expressly tied this to breach of the warranty of habitability and statutory quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14. The opinion thus directly supports using repeated flooding and failure to repair as a recognized, substantial interference with the tenancy.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (198.relevant_excerpt: “There was evidence at trial that the wall between Solomon’s apartment and the adjoining basement area was extremely porous… The jury could reasonably conclude that Gem’s failure to do so caused Solomon’s injuries — that but for Gem’s inaction, no floods would have occurred… a section of the State Sanitary Code… provides that apartments must be watertight… Gem is liable to Solomon under G. L. c. 186, § 14 because it violated its underlying duty to maintain sanitary conditions in her apartment, and thereby permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment.”

Winchester v. McCue, 385 Mass. 144, 147.proposition: Such omissions constitute a substantial interference with Plaintiff’s tenancy and quiet enjoyment, similar to the violations recognized in Sargent v. Fuller, 46 Mass. App. Ct. 909 (1999) (sustained interference through landlord’s inaction); Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (1982) (constructive eviction through repeated flooding and failure to repair); Winchester v. McCue, 385 Mass. 144, 147 (1982) (chronic leaks and disrepair amounted to breach); and Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982) (water leaks and mold held actionable).
Winchester v. McCue, 385 Mass. 144, 147.support_reasoning: This opinion is a homicide and criminal procedure case (Commonwealth v. Tavares) dealing with Miranda waivers, voluntariness of statements, jury instructions, juror misconduct, and § 33E review. It does not involve landlord–tenant law, quiet enjoyment, chronic leaks, disrepair, or any housing conditions issues. Therefore it cannot be used as authority for the proposition that chronic leaks and disrepair amount to a breach of quiet enjoyment or substantial interference with tenancy.
Winchester v. McCue, 385 Mass. 144, 147.relevant_excerpt: “With all these factors in mind, we order the verdict reduced to murder in the second degree. The order denying the motion for a new trial is affirmed. We remand this case to the Superior Court where the verdict of guilty of murder in the first degree, and the sentence previously imposed, are to be vacated. A verdict of guilty of murder in the second degree is to be entered, and sentence is to be imposed thereon.”

Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.raw_text: Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982)
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.proposition: Such omissions constitute a substantial interference with Plaintiff’s tenancy and quiet enjoyment, similar to the violations recognized in Sargent v. Fuller, 46 Mass. App. Ct. 909 (1999) (sustained interference through landlord’s inaction); Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (1982) (constructive eviction through repeated flooding and failure to repair); Winchester v. McCue, 385 Mass. 144, 147 (1982) (chronic leaks and disrepair amounted to breach); and Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982) (water leaks and mold held actionable).
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.support_reasoning: Lowery concerns failure to provide heat and holds that such failure constitutes a breach of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14; it does not discuss water leaks, mold, or analogous conditions. The proposition cites Lowery as authority that “water leaks and mold [were] held actionable,” which is inaccurate and beyond the scope of the opinion’s facts and holding. Thus, although Lowery supports substantial interference via lack of heat, it does not support the specific water‑leak/mold characterization in the proposition.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season… seriously ‘impair[s] the character and value of the leased premises’… and constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment… Thus… liability will be imposed ‘whenever the “natural and probable consequence” of [the] landlord’s action [is] interruption of the tenant’s rights.’… On the facts found by the judge, the tenant was entitled on the quiet enjoyment claim to… a declaration that the landlords had violated G. L. c. 186, § 14… and an assessment of damages and counsel fees under § 14.”

Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 3.raw_text: Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184, 200 (1973)
Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 3.proposition: Defendant’s conduct also violates the implied warranty of habitability, which informs the extent of interference actionable under the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 3.support_reasoning: This passage is from Justice Quirico’s concurrence/dissent and does not link the implied warranty of habitability to, or describe it as informing, the scope of interference actionable under the covenant of quiet enjoyment. He instead criticizes the majority’s broader implied warranty formulation and would ground landlord obligations in statutory/code standards, saying nothing about how that warranty interacts with the covenant of quiet enjoyment. The text therefore does not support the proposition that breach of the implied warranty both violates habitability and defines or informs the actionable interference under quiet enjoyment.
Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 3.relevant_excerpt: “The point at which I dissent from the opinion of the court is where it attempts to accomplish the first step by resort to an implied warranty of the fitness of the rented dwelling unit instead of by the implication of an agreement that the unit will comply with the minimum standards required therefor by law. The court states the new rule to be that the landlord renting a dwelling unit impliedly warrants to the tenant ‘that the premises are fit for human occupation….’”

Jablonski v. Clemons, 60 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Jablonski v. Clemons, 60 Mass. App. Ct. 473, 476 (2004)
Jablonski v. Clemons, 60 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Defendant’s conduct also violates the implied warranty of habitability, which informs the extent of interference actionable under the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Jablonski v. Clemons, 60 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion clearly treats breach of the implied warranty of habitability and breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment as distinct claims with different standards, rather than stating that the warranty of habitability ‘informs’ the extent of interference actionable under quiet enjoyment. The court separately analyzes habitability (significant code violations and material breach) and quiet enjoyment (serious interference and impairment of value under G.L. c. 186, § 14) and does not say that a warranty breach defines or shapes what counts as actionable interference for quiet enjoyment, even though the same facts support both claims.
Jablonski v. Clemons, 60 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt:
“Implied in every residential lease is a warranty that the leased premises are fit for human occupation… A violation of the code may (or may not) support a claim of breach of the implied warranty of habitability…

The implied covenant of quiet enjoyment guarantees tenants the right to be free from ‘serious’ interferences with their tenancies. See G. L. c. 186, § 14… A landlord violates G. L. c. 186, § 14, when its ‘acts or omissions impair the value of the leased premises.’ Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782, 789 (1994).”}

G.L. c. 111, \u00a7\u00a7127A\u2013127H.proposition: Defendant’s refusal to address health and safety hazards contravenes G.L. c. 111, §§127A–127H, requiring landlords to maintain premises in compliance with the sanitary code.

Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.raw_text: Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782, 789 (1994)
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.proposition: Plaintiff’s repeated written and verbal complaints were ignored, demonstrating deliberate or reckless disregard for her right to quiet enjoyment.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.support_reasoning: The opinion does not describe Thomas’s “repeated written and verbal complaints” being ignored. To the contrary, the court repeatedly notes that Cruz Management made repeated, though negligent and ineffectual, attempts to repair and respond to her complaints. The case holds that negligent failure to adequately correct known defects can violate G.L. c. 186, § 14, but it does not frame the conduct as deliberate or reckless disregard based on ignoring complaints.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.relevant_excerpt: “Since the evidence indicated that the ineffectual attempts were made to respond to the tenant’s complaints, only negligent conduct was shown. In the judge’s opinion, this was not sufficient to establish liability under § 14. … Cruz Management had notice of numerous sanitary, building and fire code violations in the apartment… It was wholly foreseeable … that the failure adequately to correct these violations… would impair substantially the value of the leased premises… On the facts found by the judge a violation of § 14 has been shown.”
